pageContext.claim: “There have been 29 times a vacancy open during an election year or prior to an inauguration, 29 times, that's a lot. Every single time, the sitting president made a nomination. That included, did you ever hear of George Washington? Did you ever hear of Thomas Jefferson? Or how about the great Abraham Lincoln, where he wore the hottest fashion with the great hat.”
pageContext.analysis: Actually, a Supreme Court seat became available 27 days before the 1864 election. (On Oct. 12, 1864, Chief Justice Roger B. Taney died at the age of 87.) Lincoln didn’t nominate anyone until after he won.
